An extension field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. This field is uniquely characterized up to isomorphism as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Does the concept of a/an Extension Field need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois group of a Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an Extension Field is fundamental to the definition of the Galois group of a Field Extension. The definition of the Galois group explicitly mentions an 'extension $L / K$', which implies that $L$ is an extension field of $K$. Without the concept of an extension field, the notion of automorphisms that fix every element of a base field $K$ while operating on an extended field $L$ would not make sense. Therefore, understanding what an extension field is, is crucial to defining and understanding the Galois group of that extension. The definition of an extension field provided, although specific to finite fields, illustrates the general concept of one field being an extension of another, which is necessary for the concept of a Galois group.
